docs.lead_paragraph: In the fall of 1984, when President Ronald Reagan was on a triumphal march to re-election and Southern Democrats feared devastating losses across their region, Victor Ashe, a Republican candidate for Senate in Tennessee, was stalled and frustrated in his campaign against Al Gore Jr. Mr. Ashe was trying, mightily, to tie Mr. Gore to his national party, its liberal image and its doomed nominee, Walter F. Mondale, but it was not working. ''Al Gore described himself in those days as a raging moderate,'' Mr. Ashe, now the mayor of Knoxville, recalls.

headline.main: Shifting Views Over Abortion Fog Gore Race

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore's position on abortion, how it has changed over 15 years since he ran for US Senate in Tennessee, and why it is now a source of bitter and growing contention in race for Democratic nomination for president; Bill Bradley, Gore's opponent in Democratic primaries, is running television ads in New York that say that Bradley is 'the only candidate who's always been pro-choice;' Gore said last week that while he voted against federal financing for abortions in late 1970's and early 1980's he had abandoned that position as he came to realize that it carries 'an inequitable result'; says he has always supported Roe v. Wade; but Gore's efforts to minimize how much his position has changed over the years has fueled controversy; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans Inc. said today that it earned $268 million in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss in the quarter a year earlier and beating Wall Street's estimates. Oxford, one of the biggest health insurers in New York, said its profit was in contrast to a loss of $7.95 million in the 1998 period.

headline.main: Oxford Health Returns to Profit in Quarter

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc says it earned $268 million in fourth quarter, reversing loss in quarter a year earlier and beating Wall Street expectations; says sales fell to $1.03 billion from $1.13 billion, partly because it left some markets where it was too small to compete effectively (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-seven terminally ill Oregonians, mostly older cancer patients, used the nation's only law on assisted suicide to end their lives in 1999, up from 16 the year before. Oregon health officials said reports from doctors and patients' families indicated that those who used the state's Death with Dignity Act did so out of a desire to have some control over the way they died.

headline.main: Suicide Assistance Is Increasing, Oregon Says

docs.abstract: Oregon, which has nation's only law on assisted suicide to end life of terminally ill patients, says 27 such people, mostly older cancer patients, used law to end their lives in 1999, up from 16 in previous year; opponents of law say it is immoral to have doctors assist in suicides; effort is under way in Congress to derail law and to prevent other states from passing similar measures (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey's top lawmaker said yesterday that he supported a proposal to let doctors negotiate which procedures would be covered by health maintenance organizations, and their reimbursement rates. The State Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, expressed support for the measure during a Senate Health Committee hearing on a range of health care issues. Mr. DiFrancesco, a likely Republican candidate for governor next year, also said he would consider giving patients the right to sue H.M.O.'s.

headline.main: Let Doctors Judge Care By H.M.O.'s, Senator Says

docs.abstract: New Jersey Sen pres Donald T DiFrancesco supports proposal to let doctors negotiate which procedures would be covered by health maintenance organizations and their reimbursement rates (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore paused in their attacks today to announce proposals for social programs. Mr. Bradley proposed federally financed earnings insurance to compensate workers who take salary cuts as a result of global trade.

headline.main: 2 Democrats Present Plans About Drugs And Workers

docs.abstract: Former Sen Bill Bradley and Vice Pres Al Gore pause in their attacks to announce proposals for social programs; Bradley proposes federally financed earnings insurance to compensate workers who take salary cuts as result of global trade; says he supports free trade but seeks to buffer American workers from its worst side effects; Gore offers proposal to help people on Medicare pay for prescription drugs which Bradley claims sounds like his own proposal; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a measure of Bill Bradley's distance from the real world of power politics in this country that he seems somehow to have convinced himself that he can revive his presidential campaign by winning the nonbinding Democratic primary in the state of Washington. So he's gone off to the great Northwest, which is probably a more congenial place for the cerebral former senator than some of the bigger, noisier primary states like New York and California.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says Bill Bradley's recent behavior raises question about whether his heart is still in the presidential race; says he seems adept at skirting practical reality of world of politics, suggesting grand themes that have no possibility of being implemented; says rather than campaign for votes in New York and California, two vast and crucial states, Bradley is currently campaigning in state of Washington for its nonbinding Democratic primary (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a nod to President Clinton's continuing popularity among Democratic voters, former Senator Bill Bradley asserted today that Vice President Al Gore had adopted many core Democratic principles only after becoming Mr. Clinton's ''No. 2,'' and he suggested that the vice president could not be counted on to defend those principles on his own. Though he has criticized Mr. Clinton's ethics in the past, the former senator from New Jersey twice wrapped himself in the president's mantle today, saying he and Mr. Clinton shared views on universal health care, and contending that Mr. Gore had forsaken that goal.

headline.main: Bradley Nod To Clinton On Universal Health Care

docs.abstract: Democratic presidential candidate former Sen Bill Bradley campaigns in Astoria, New York City; wraps himself in Pres Clinton's mantle despite earlier criticisms by stating that he and Clinton share views on universal health care; says Vice Pres Al Gore has forsaken goal; says Gore adopted many core Democratic principles only after becoming Vice President and cannot be counted on to defend principles on his own; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Did not! Did so! Perhaps the only players who came out ahead in Monday night's fractious Democratic debate were the opposition research teams for the Gore and Bradley campaigns, gnomes who puzzle over 20-year-old votes and speeches that drew only minimal attention when they happened.

headline.main: Charges at Debate Have Core of Truth Tinted by Spin

docs.abstract: Article assesses accuracy of statements made by Vice Pres Al Gore and former Sen Bill Bradley during Democratic presidental debate at Apollo Theater in Harlem; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone tuning in to the Democratic debate Monday night saw two extremely aggressive candidates going full tilt at each other. Bill Bradley, who trails Vice President Al Gore in all the polls, had obvious reasons to try to make his mark. But Mr. Gore's nostril-flaring performance, and his combative campaigning over the last few weeks, have raised questions about why, when he appears to be so far ahead in the race for the party's presidential nomination, he feels the need to be so pugnacious.

headline.main: Gore Cultivates Image as a Fighter

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore's combative and pugnacious posture in Democratic presidential debate with former Sen Bill Bradley at Apollo Theater in Harlem mirrors his posture in campaign at large; he wants world to know he is fighter--quality he must assert to prod core Democrats to primaries and reputation he needs to build to woo independents (M)
